newsitem.title: UK: LME has no control over non-exchange stocks.
newsitem.headline: LME has no control over non-exchange stocks.

text.p: The London Metal Exchange (LME) said on Thursday that it has no control over metal stocks held outside its reporting system.
"The LME has no legal jurisdiction or regulatory control over stocks maintained by producers, fabricators, merchants or others outside its system," it said.
The LME was responding to reports of large stocks of copper held outside its warehousing system.
On Wednesday, the World Bureau of Metal Statistics (WBMS) reported that nearly 600,000 tonnes of non-LME copper may have built up in Netherlands bonded warehouses between 1991 and 1995.
The LME said that it cannot require such stocks to be reported to it.
"Consequently, it is unable to comment upon the existence or the extent of such stocks. Nor, indeed is it in any position to know whether such stocks would be of LME-registered brands," it said.
All LME-approved warehouses are required to report regularly twice-weekly the movements of all stocks entering and leaving.
Such information is made public, and all LME warehouses are regularly reminded about their obligations to comply with these requirements, the LME added.
